sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1:
Find the inverse of the following 2x2 matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 3 \\
1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix}
d & -b \\
-c & a
\end{bmatrix}$$

where A is the given matrix:

$$A = \begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 3 \\
1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}$$

and det(A) is the determinant of A:

$$\text{det}(A) = ad - bc$$

First, let's find the determinant of A:

$$\text{det}(A) = (2)(4) - (3)(1) = 8 - 3 = 5$$

Now, we can find the inverse of A using the formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix}
d & -b \\
-c & a
\end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{5} \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -3 \\
-1 & 2
\end{bmatrix}$$

Finally, multiply each element by the scalar 1/5:

$$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{4}{5} & \frac{-3}{5} \\
\frac{-1}{5} & \frac{2}{5}
\end{bmatrix}$$
